title: In 2016 will the Permanent Court of Arbitration rule that China's "nine-dash line" is contrary to the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS)?
preds:
https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/beijing-remains-angry-defiant-and-defensive-as-key-south-china-sea-tribunal-ruling-looms/2016/07/12/11100f48-4771-11e6-8dac-0c6e4accc5b1_story.html
The Washington Post seems to think so, assuming their quote is accurate:
"The tribunal ruled that 'there was no legal basis for China to claim historic rights to resources ... within the sea areas falling within the "nine-dash line".'"

Just in from The Permanent Court of Arbitration "China has 'no legal basis' to claim historic rights in South China Sea UN Tribunal finds " http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-07-12/china-no-legal-basis-south-china-sea-tribunal-finds/7622738

Let's do pay attention to the question.  If the Court ducks the 9-dash-line issue tomorrow--which if anybody cares is what I expect, although they will find for the Philippines--that doesn't make this a No.  In theory another proceeding could be lodged by the Philippines or somebody else.
I am forecasting based on the general news reports and GJP consensus.

No court will use the pro or con of "nine dash line" in a decision. This court can only rule on specific features of disputed outcroppings. Rival claims between Philippines, Vietnam, Malaysea in SCS over same "nine dash line" will not be attempted to be resolved and if the court even claims to settle, or even use the "nine dash line" phrase in its ruling, it will be amazing.
Since "nine dash line" is in quotes in this question, if that specific phrase is not used in the ruling, this question must resolve as zero, no matter how much pundits claim the ruling settles this or that, the question is specific, the ruling must specify what GJO asks or language means nothing and quotation marks must be banned from future questions.
Unchanged at 3%..

"China's bases its South China Sea claim on a so-called "Nine Dash line" stretching deep into the maritime heart of southeast Asia and covering hundreds of disputed islands and reefs, rich fishing grounds and oil and gas deposits.
"A ruling against Beijing "would deprive China of any legal basis for making such a claim," Paul Reichler, the Philippines' chief lawyer in the case told Reuters"
The court's decision is expected the 12th. For reference:
Court announced they will issue a ruling on July 12th so will remove the following adjustments from my forecast:
The 9 Dash line is not recognized by UNCLOS- expect Permanent Court to reaffirm non-recognition

I pdfed the jurisdictional decision from the Hague. They have jurisdiction over all but maritime boundary claims.
9 dash line is an EEZ claim. Phillipines first and second submissions require resolution.
An arbitration panel can state in the  AWARD,whatever it wants. Phillipines can request clarification.  
See Hague jurisdiction decision. I word searched it for "nine-dash line" and "merits".
Best call I can make @anneinak
Revising downward, per comment of @Anneinak below, and the other forecaster comments she links to.

For the first time in my life, I recently hired an attorney to prepare an advice letter on an issue.  In so doing, I learned many things, one of which is that one must be as careful with attorneys as one is with God with what one asks for, because that's likely what one will get. The attorney answered the question exactly as it was stated, not as it was intended.
When I read that the Permanent Court of Arbitration may rule on July 7th, I thought I should check my forecast.
I am forecasting based on the general news reports and GJP consensus.
Interesting article on the subject looking at some potential outcomes.

Validating China's claim will set a dangerous precedent, as countries will then have overlapping territories, which could lead to tensions and war between countries, which no rational country would want. The law of the sea is widely accepted by all nations and will he upheld.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Dropping from an old 99% to 96%.
Am increasingly reluctant to go above 95% in forecasts.
Increasing the chances that Duterte withdraws the claim to 3% on the basis that China may concede something through back channels, which drops my forecast to 89%.
Part of Wests effort to limit Chinese claims in SCS.

That will be the result, the timing could technically be thrown off by some delay or other, but that seems unlikely.
Of course that being said I'd give the same likelihood that China will declare the ruling "illegal" or "non-binding".
Staying with a prediction of almost certainly:
Lowering further, based on this analysis (from 27 april 2016): http://maritimeawarenessproject.org/2016/04/27/forecasting-the-south-china-sea-arbitration-merits-award/

http://amti.csis.org/ArbitrationTL/index.html
Great timeline. This seems inevitable but @Aches thank you for the thoughtful note expressing the contrary view. You may well be right.
After some research, I'm lowering my forecast to 10 percent.

I've let my forecast get stale. We're getting closer to the date, there has been greater US activity near Phillipines, which doesn't directly influence UNCLOS (especially since US isn't a party), but it's probably an indication that the international community's sentiment is increasingly becoming firm on this particular issue. No court is entirely impartial, and a ruling in China's favor would be highly detrimental to pretty much all the other members of UNCLOS. Increasing my forecast to 95% from 82%.

The only country that accepts China's nine-dash rule is China itself. And given President Xi's obvious willingness to expand and militarize the South China Sea, the question is whether the international community will allow this. I find it highly unlikely that China's expansionism will be accepted.

Holding, but watching for this possible delay:
http://indianexpress.com/article/business/business-others/taiwan-enters-south-china-sea-legal-fray-as-group-seeks-to-sway-international-court/

After May and June and especially September, any futher delay would start raising time decay and reducing. The Phillipine election is over, there seems no reason that the panel would delay, and in fact the US and Aquino have a big interest in finalizing an unenforecable court arbitation as part of their international law initiative.
Not giving 100% forecasts anymore when crowd consensus is nearby.

The international Arbitral Tribunal on Thursday decided on several issues in the maritime dispute case between China and the Philippines over the South China Sea (West Philippine Sea), majority of which involved rejecting Chinaâ€™s arguments.
Yes, it will. But China will not care as it views the PCoA as a pro-Western court.

Weighing in on this, thanks to a link from @dkc below.
China is not sending representation to the court as a sign of protest. They have been assigned representation, but the boycott is indicative of the weak case that China can make under UNCLOS.
G7 countries are promoting a positive outcome in favour of the Philippines.
twitter feed and bloomberg law and Stratfor

In order for China's "nine-dash line" to be congruent with UNCLOS historical effective control must be proven. Though there are some islands within the the area that China has established settlements on, and more recently constructed military bases upon, there is no evidence of continued effective control within the entirety of the 'nine-dash line".

I don't suppose there is any hope of getting the Nice People In Charge Here to give us a hint about whether any finding for the Philippines is a Yes.  That would require them to put some thought into the issue.  The question seems remarkably clear for a change, but I no longer trust these people to know what they mean when they say things.

I increasingly see little room for this resolving in the negative unless GJO decides to make a stringent interpretation of the ruling. I doubt that will happen because a ruling in favour of The Philippines will be covered by international press as a declaration that 9-dashed line is contrary to UNCLOS, regardless of whether the ruling technically says that. My impression is that this will be enough to sway the determinators.

Arbitration panel of EU members will declare the 9-line dead implicitly when it recognizes Phillipines claims See CNN International http://www.cnn.com/2016/03/26/asia/taiwan-south-china-sea/
compare and contrast prc'S CLaims IN 3 fm RELEASES.
Taiping island, South China Sea (CNN)Taiwan claims to have continuously occupied this postage stamp-sized island in the azure waters of the South China Sea for 60 years.
"This is the Chinese navy, this is the Chinese navy. Please go away," a Chinese radio operator announced in one of at least eight warnings to the aircraft. ( that is not a ADIZ under Sen. McCain definition)" In October, the Chinese government summoned the U.S. ambassador to Beijing to issue a formal protest after the destroyer USS Lassen sailed within 12 nautical miles of the Chinese-controlled Subi Reef in the Spratlys.

Interesting to see so many top forecasters hovering in the mid-80s. Isn't there some rule of probability that says: "If a bunch of people research different sources, and all think that something will probably happen, add a little extra probability to account for the hypothetical impact of the extra sources"? That's what I'll do here, cutting half the distance to the goal.
China will try to delay the proceedings and a decision in 2016, and the Court will try to avoid making a strong stand against a P-5 UN member, despite the merits of the case.
They should, but China has a lot of sway with the UN.
The 9-dash line is an arbitrary, egregious departure from the intent and substance of UNCLOS.

With rare exceptions, courts will not rule on an issue that hasn't been presented as part of somebody's argument.  Since the Philippines' argument reportedly doesn't mention the line and China are not presenting an argument, the court can find for the Philippines on the merits of the case with respect to individual rocks, which is probably what will happen.  The Chinese will ignore any ruling anyway, but there is no reason to irritate them gratuitously.
I don't think this arbitration court will have the guts to rule against China. I just don't feel it happening.

After reviewing similar cases (involving application of the UNCLOS) presented before PCA, I concluded that 20% of the cases were terminated prior to hearing, one of the parties withdrawing its motion. And the result for the remainder is usually so that neither party is completely satisfied. 
Also looking at various news sources, I move my answer to 84%.

Current status of What is to be Done in Philippines related to UNCLOS : http://www.huffingtonpost.com/daniel-wagner/much-remains-to-be-done-i_b_9393568.html
Why Chine should be concerned : http://www.huffingtonpost.com/daniel-wagner/china-should-be-concerned_b_8461618.html
Wikipedia: "China refuses to participate in the arbitration". A unchallenged and therefore easy judgment to make.

They should, but there is a small chance that and ruling will be delayed so there might not be a decision in 2016. Anyway, the Chinese will not care about any such rule, so it won't change the difficult situation in the South China Sea.

I am continuing on the unsubstantiated assumption that a Yes here will require the Court to "rule that China's 'nine-dash line' is contrary to [UNCLOS]," that being the plain wording of the question.  If they just issue rulings that only undermine or even effectively obliterate the line, but don't stomp on it in terms, that's a No.  I haven't read the actual documents, but suppose that @dom_ma is correct that the Philippines' petitions do not mention the line as such; since the Court hasn't been asked about this, they need not rule on it.
Following Argentina finding UNCLOS expand territories
Two questions: will the court rule against China, and will the court rule before end 2016- combined prob very low.

My recollection is that China has refused to advocate its case in arbitration, and the Philippine case is pretty strong.  Last I checked, the ruling is expected in April or May, but in 2016 in any case.  What is a more sporting proposition is what China will do about it.  But that is literally another question.
Historical recognition of previously agreed facts, deciding otherwise would undermine similar decisions.  2016 not 100% given delaying pressure from China (and supporters) to NOT pass it
Some things in life can always be relied upon, like the unavoidable necessity of taking good strategic positions in geopolitics.

New information for me: A pro-Philippines ruling from the Court, specifically as it relates to status of islands/rocks & ability to claim 200mi EEZ, could potentially effect claims made by US & other Western countries from rocks/islands that we hold. So while could be negative for China, precedent set that benefits Philippines could negatively impact west, even tho US is not party to UNCLOS.

There will almost certainly be a finding for the Philippines in this case, but the Court can achieve that without negating the nine-dash line in terms.  If they choose the narrower path, you can chalk it up to either (a) commendable judicial restraint, in the sense of not issuing a ruling broader than needed to settle the instant issue; or (b) despicable political cowardice, in the sense of not issuing a ruling that will piss off the Chinese.
Stated ruling date, and by law it appears that the Chinese position on  9 dash is an overreach
Countries will be unwilling to pick a fight with China while the global economy remains rocky.
very unlikely given China's seat at the Council
Yes, based on law, but China will ignore the ruling.
The International Court of Arbitration are yet to decide whether they have jurisdiction over the submission relating to this question.
China is in violation of international law.
Chinese arguments have virtually no legal support.g
The rest of the world needs China to not devalue the Yuan so is more likely to accommodate them on other issues.
China setting up maritime judicially center is an indicator that ruling will be against her.
But Security council will veto, or China will ignore.

This is trickier than it may appear, I think. In terms of anybody's notion of international law, the nine-dash line is a nonsense.  China expects to lose this case, of course, which is why they've already announced they'll be paying no attention to the ruling.  However, I'm pretty sure the case doesn't require a ruling on the line as such, only on a specific and limited claim.  The Court could rule on that claim and never mention the nine-dash line at all.  In fact, I'm having trouble thinking of how you'd frame a question so that the Court would ever have to rule on the legality of the nine-dash line.

The Philippines arguments  under UNCLOS. are unassailable.

PCA does not rule in 2016 2% -  all the commentators and the Philippines seem to indicate a decision is imminent, but I can't find anywhere where PCA has committed to make a decision this year - if anyone has seen something to the contrary please let me know.

Not much chance the Court will uphold the nine-dash line as such, but complications are always possible.  Taiwan says this hunk of rock is an island and claims it, but China of course claims Taiwan and all its goods and chattels.  That seems a separate issue from the nine-dash line as such, but lawyers can do marvelous things if properly instructed, motivated, and paid.

I'm lowering my forecast a bit, because this question could resolve early for "No" if the UNCLOS decides the China's nine-dash line is OK.  I still think there is about an 80% chance that the Court will find against the nine-dash line.

They are still hearing. "The Tribunal said that it will set further hearings to discuss merits and the jurisdiction of remaining issues and that it expects to be able to make a final decision in 2016."  May be, It will be more discussions.

China is boycotting the case and says it will ignore the verdict, leading me to believe that UNCLOS will rule in favor of Philippines,  because the end result will be the same: China will just continue to ignore UNCLOS authority.
Raising % based on more time to assess question. Still same logic.
Prior precedent isn't favourable, and the fact that Zhongguo has refused to accept the court's authority suggests that it doesn't expect the ruling to be in its favour.

The Permanent Court of Arbitration will rule against China's nine dash line claim because the documents on which the Chinese are basing their claim are not recognized by any other country in the world. Furthermore, all the countries in the surrounding area plus the Americans will never allow China to be in control of such a strategically located and vast body of water, especially since China is the country farthest from the area it is claiming.
The Americans.will never allow the Chinese to claim such a vast and strategic area.
Well, the big issue is, what is the nine-dash line supposedly representing?

It is unlikely that the court will rule in a way which will demonstrate how powerless it is with respect to this situation.  I would expect either a delay in the judgement or an answer so unclear that it would rival something out of the oracle of Delphi.  Because is going to take control of the South China Sea is inevitable without regard to the court ruling thus the court will not give a definitive judgement.  The Phililppines, VietNam, Malaysia and Indonesia should see the writing on the wall and begin whatever accommodation needed to live with this reality.

The US is commited to nixing this 9Dash line thing. They sent a whole battle group for freedom of navigation manuevers. China has rocks in their head if they think it will work. For some reason they think the US will back down, maybe they believe their own propaganda.
Reaffirming my opening probability assessment, but wanted to provide some pertinent info:

I've come down on the SCS ADIZ, but I think there will still be alot of pushback from the international community to pre-emptively keep that from happening. So starting high:)
http://www.ibtimes.co.in/indonesia-summons-chinese-ambassador-after-stand-off-over-fishing-boat-671522
too explosive an issue for early decision

The nine dash line precedes UNCLOS and has some validity. I am sure any decision reached by arbitration will not be recognized by China.  Any decision reached will probably be sufficiently weak and unenforceable and nothing will be resolved.

I believe the court will rule against China in this case, but will it matter?  China has already indicated they would not seek out the international court to rule on this issue and even if the court rules against China, China will not adhere to the ruling.

The nine-dash line is a HUGE swath of territory. Upholding nine-dash line totally in favor of China would override long-standing maritime law dealing with Exclusive Economic Zones (EEZ). It would marginalize several countries beyond the Philippines (Vietnam, Brunei, Malaysia, and Taiwan) including rights of navigation.
China is managing to anger just about all of it's nautical neighbors: http://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/22/world/asia/indonesia-south-china-sea-fishing-boat.html
